statement.p:
Suppose f(x) is a function that we approximated by F(x). Further, suppose f(10)=-3, while our approximation was F(10)=5. Let R(x)=f(x)-F(x).
True or false: |R(10)| \leq 7
True or false: |R(10)| \leq 8
True or false: |R(10)| \leq 9
True or false: |R(10)| \leq 100

solution.p:
From the given information,
|R(10)|=|f(10)-F(10)|=|-3-5|=|-8|=8
So, (a) is false (since 8 is not less than or equal to 7), while (b), (c), and (d) are true.

Remark: R(x) is the error in our approximation. As mentioned in the text, we almost never know R exactly, but we can give a bound. We don't need the tightest bound--just a reasonable one that is easy to calculate. If we were dealing with real functions and approximations, we might not know that |R(10)|=8, but if we knew it was at most 9, that would be a pretty decent approximation.

Often in this section, we will make simplifying assumptions to get a bound that is easy to calculate. But, don't go overboard! It is a true statement to say that our absolute error is at most 100, but this statement would probably not be very helpful as a bound.

statement.p:
Let f(x)=e^x, and let T_3(x) be the third order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x),
T_3(x)=1+x+\frac{1}{2}x^2+\frac{1}{3!}x^3
Use Equation to give a reasonable bound on the error |f(2)-T_3(2)|. Then, find the error |f(2)-T_3(2)| using a calculator.

hint.p: for some c strictly between 0 and 2.

answer.p: Equation gives us the bound |f(2)-T_3(2)| \lt 6. A calculator tells us actually |f(2)-T_3(2)|\approx 1.056.

solution.p:
Equation tells us that, when T_n(x) is the nth order Taylor polynomial for a function f(x) about x=a, then
|f(x)-T_n(x)| &= \left|\frac{f^{(n+1)}(c)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}\right|
for some c strictly between x and a. In our case, n=3, a=0, x=2, and f^{(4)}(c)=e^c, so |f(2)-T_3(2)| &= \left|\frac{f^{(4)}(c)}{4!}(2-0)^4\right|
&=\frac{2^4}{4!}e^c=\frac{2}{3}e^c
Since c is strictly between 0 and 2, e^c \lt e^2: &\leq \frac{2}{3}e^2
but this isn't a number we really know. Indeed: e^2 is the very number we're trying to approximate. So, we use the estimation e \lt 3: & \lt \frac{2}{3}\cdot 3^2 =6
We conclude that the error |f(2)-T_3(2)| is less than 6.

Now we'll get a more exact idea of the error using a calculator. (Calculators will also only give approximations of numbers like e, but they are generally very good approximations.)
|f(2)-T_3(2)|&=\left|e^2-\left(1+2+\frac{1}{2}\cdot2^2+\frac{1}{3!}\cdot2^3\right)\right|
&=\left|e^2-\left(1+2+2+\frac{4}{3}\right)\right|
&=\left|e^2-\frac{19}{3}\right| \approx 1.056
So, our actual answer was only off by about 1.
Remark: 1 \lt 6, so this does not in any way contradict our bound |f(2)-T_3(2)| \lt 6.

statement.p: Let f(x)= 5x^3-24x^2+ex-\pi^4, and let T_5(x) be the fifth order Taylor polynomial for f(x) about x=1. Give the best bound you can on the error |f(37)-T(37)|.

hint.p: You are approximating a third order polynomial with a fifth order Taylor polynomial. You should be able to tell how good your approximation will be without a long calculation.

solution.p: Whenever you approximate a polynomial with a Taylor polynomial of greater or equal degree, your Taylor polynomial is exactly the same as the function you are approximating. So, the error is zero.

statement.p: You and your friend both want to approximate \sin(33). Your friend uses the first order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x)=\sin x, while you use the zeroth order (constant) Maclaurin polynomial for f(x)=\sin x. Who has a better approximation, you or your friend?

hint.p: Draw a picture it should be clear how the two approximations behave.

solution.p:
The constant approximation gives
\sin(33)&\approx \sin (0)=0
while the linear approximation gives f(x)&\approx f(0)+f'(0)x
\sin(x)& \approx \sin (0)+\cos(0) x &= x
\sin(33)&\approx 33
Since -1 \leq \sin(33)\leq 1, the constant approximation is better. (But both are a little silly.)

statement.p: Suppose a function f(x) has sixth derivative f^{(6)}(x)=\dfrac{6!(2x-5)}{x+3}. Let T_5(x) be the 5th order Taylor polynomial for f(x) about x=11.
Give a bound for the error |f(11.5)-T_5(11.5)|.

hint.p:
In this case, Equation tells us that
\left|f(11.5)-T_5(11.5)\right| = \left|\dfrac{f^{(6)}(c)}{6!}(11.5-11)^{6}\right| for some c strictly between 11 and 11.5.

solution.p:
Equation tells us that, when T_n(x) is the nth order Taylor polynomial for a function f(x) about x=a, then
|f(x)-T_n(x)| &= \left|\frac{f^{(n+1)}(c)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}\right|
for some c strictly between x and a. In our case, n=5, a=11, x=11.5, and f^{(6)}(c)=\dfrac{6!(2c-5)}{c+3}. \left|f(11.5)-T_5(11.5)\right|& = \left|\dfrac{1}{6!}\left(\dfrac{6!(2c-5)}{c+3}\right)(11.5-11)^{6}\right|
& = \left|\dfrac{2c-5}{c+3}\right|\cdot\frac{1}{2^6}
for some c in (11,11.5). We don't know exactly which c this is true for, but since we know that c lies in (11,11.5), we can provide bounds.
2c-5 \lt 2(11.5)-5=18
c+3 \gt 11+3=14
Therefore, \left|\dfrac{2c-5}{c+3}\right|=\dfrac{2c-5}{c+3} \lt \dfrac{18}{14}=\dfrac{9}{7} when c \in (11,11.5).
With this bound, we see
|f(11.5)-T_5(11.5)| &= \left|\dfrac{2c-5}{c+3}\right|\cdot\frac{1}{2^6}
& \lt \left(\frac{9}{7}\right)\left(\frac{1}{ 2^6}\right)\approx 0.0201
Our error is less than 0.02.

statement.p: Let f(x)= \tan x, and let T_2(x) be the second order Taylor polynomial for f(x) about x=0. Give a reasonable bound on the error |f(0.1)-T(0.1)| using Equation.

hint.p: In this case, Equation tells us that \left|f(0.1)-T_2(0.1)\right| = \left|\dfrac{f^{(3)}(c)}{3!}(0.1-0)^{3}\right| for some c strictly between 0 and 0.1.

solution.p:
Equation tells us that, when T_n(x) is the nth order Taylor polynomial for a function f(x) about x=a, then
|f(x)-T_n(x)| &= \left|\frac{f^{(n+1)}(c)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}\right|
for some c strictly between x and a. In our case, n=2, a=0, and x=0.1, so \left|f(0.1)-T_2(0.1)\right| &= \left|\frac{f^{(3)}(c)}{3!}(0.1-0)^{3}\right|
&=\frac{\left|f'''(c)\right|}{6000}
for some c in (0,0.1).

statement.p: Let f(x)=\log (1-x), and let T_5(x) be the fifth order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x). Use Equation to give a bound on the error |f\left(-\frac{1}{4}\right)-T_5\left(-\frac{1}{4}\right)|.
(Remember \log x=\log_ex, the natural logarithm of x.)

hint.p:
In our case, Equation tells us
\left|f\left(-\dfrac{1}{4}\right)-T_5\left(-\dfrac{1}{4}\right)\right| = \left|\dfrac{f^{(6)}(c)}{6!}\left(-\dfrac{1}{4}-0\right)^6\right|

solution.p:
We're interested in an upper bound for the error: we want to know the worst case scenario, so we can say that the error is no worse than that. We need to know what the biggest possible value of \dfrac{1}{6\cdot 4^6 \cdot (1-c)^6} is, given -\dfrac{1}{4} \lt c \lt 0. That means we want to know the biggest possible value of \dfrac{1}{(1-c)^6}. This corresponds to the smallest possible value of (1-c)^6, which in turn corresponds to the smallest absolute value of 1-c.
Since -\dfrac{1}{4}\leq c \leq 0, the smallest absolute value of 1-c occurs when c=0. In other words, |1-c| \leq 1.
That means the smallest possible value of (1-c)^6 is 1^6=1.
Then the largest possible value of \dfrac{1}{(1-c)^6} is 1.
Then the largest possible value of \dfrac{1}{6\cdot 4^6}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(1-c)^6} is \dfrac{1}{6\cdot 4^6}\approx 0.0000407.
Finally, we conclude
\left|f\left(-\frac{1}{4}\right)-T_5\left(-\frac{1}{4}\right)\right| =\frac{1}{6\cdot 4^6 \cdot (1-c)^6} \lt \dfrac{1}{6\cdot 4^6} \lt 0.00004

statement.p: Let f(x)=\sqrt[5]{x}, and let T_3(x) be the third order Taylor polynomial for f(x) about x=32. Give a bound on the error |f(30)-T_3(30)|.

hint.p: In this case, Equation tells us that \left|f(30)-T_3(30)\right| = \left|\dfrac{f^{(4)}(c)}{4!}(30-32)^{4}\right| for some c strictly between 30 and 32.

answer.p: Your answer may vary. One reasonable answer is \left|f(30)-T_3(30)\right| \lt \dfrac{14}{5^7\cdot9\cdot15} \lt 0.000002.

solution.p:
Equation tells us that, when T_n(x) is the nth order Taylor polynomial for a function f(x) about x=a, then
|f(x)-T_n(x)| &= \left|\frac{f^{(n+1)}(c)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}\right|
for some c strictly between x and a. In our case, n=3, a=30, and x=32, so |f(30)-T_3(30)| &= \left|\frac{f^{(4)}(c)}{4!}(30-32)^{4}\right|
&=\frac{2}{3}\left|f^{(4)}(c)\right|
for some c in (30,32).

statement.p: Let f(x)= \sin\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right), and let T_1(x) be the first order Taylor polynomial for f(x) about x=\dfrac{1}{\pi}. Give a bound on the error |f(0.01)-T_1(0.01)|, using Equation. You may leave your answer in terms of \pi.
Then, give a reasonable bound on the error |f(0.01)-T_1(0.01)|.

hint.p: In our case, Equation tells us \left|f\left(0.01\right)-T_1\left(0.01\right)\right| = \left|\dfrac{f^{(2)}(c)}{2!}\left(0.01-\frac{1}{\pi}\right)^2\right| for some c between 0.01 and \dfrac{1}{\pi}.

answer.p: A more reasonable bound on the error is that it is less than 5.

solution.p:
Equation tells us that, when T_n(x) is the nth order Taylor polynomial for a function f(x) about x=a, then
|f(x)-T_n(x)| &= \left|\frac{f^{(n+1)}(c)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}\right|
for some c strictly between x and a. In our case, n=1, a=\dfrac{1}{\pi}, and x=0.01, so |f(0.01)-T_1(0.01)| &= \left|\frac{f''(c)}{2}\left(0.01-\frac{1}{\pi}\right)^{2}\right|
&=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{100-\pi}{100\pi}\right)^2\cdot\left|f''(c)\right|
for some c in \left(\frac{1}{100},\frac{1}{\pi}\right).

Now we can plug in a better expression for f''(c):
|f(0.01)-T_1(0.01)| &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{100-\pi}{200\pi}\right)^2\cdot\left|f''(c)\right|
&=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{100-\pi}{100\pi}\right)^2\cdot \frac{\left|2c\cos\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)-\sin\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)\right|}{c^4}
for some c in \left(\frac{1}{100},\frac{1}{\pi}\right).

What we want to do now is find an upper bound on this expression containing c, \dfrac{1}{2}\left(\dfrac{100-\pi}{100\pi}\right)^2\cdot \dfrac{\left|2c\cos\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)-\sin\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)\right|}{c^4} .
Since c \geq \dfrac{1}{100}, it follows that c^4 \geq \dfrac{1}{100^4}, so \dfrac{1}{c^4}\leq 100^4.
For any value of x, |\cos x| and |\sin x| are at most 1. Since |c| \lt 1, also |c\cos\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)| \lt |\cos\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)| \leq 1. So, \left|2c\cos\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)-\sin\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)\right| \lt 3
Therefore,
\amp|f(0.01)-T_n(0.01)|
\amp\hskip0.5in =\,\dfrac{1}{2}\left(\dfrac{100-\pi}{100\pi}\right)^2\cdot\frac{1}{c^4}\cdot \left|2c\cos\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)-\sin\left(\frac{1}{c}\right)\right|
\amp\hskip0.5in \lt\,\dfrac{1}{2}\left(\dfrac{100-\pi}{100\pi}\right)^2\cdot100^4\cdot3
\amp\hskip0.5in=\,\frac{3\cdot 100^2}{2}\left(\frac{100}{\pi}-1\right)^2
Equation gives the bound |f(0.01)-T_1(0.01)| \leq \frac{3\cdot 100^2}{2}\left(\frac{100}{\pi}-1\right)^2.

The bound above works out to approximately fourteen million. One way to understand why the bound is so high is that \sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) moves about crazily when x is near zero--it moves up and down incredibly fast, so a straight line isn't going to approximate it very well at all.

That being said, because \sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) is still sine of something, we know -1 \leq f\left(0.01\right) \leq 1. To get a better bound on the error, let's find T_1(x).
f(x)&=\sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) & f\left(\frac{1}{\pi}\right)&=\sin(\pi)=0
f'(x)&=\frac{-\cos\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}{x^2} & f'\left(\frac{1}{\pi}\right)&=-\pi^2\cos(\pi)=\pi^2
T_1(x)&=f\left(\frac{1}{\pi}\right)+f'\left(\frac{1}{\pi}\right)\left(x-\frac{1}{\pi}\right)
&=0+\pi^2\left(x-\frac{1}{\pi}\right) &=\pi^2x-\pi
T_1\left(0.01\right)& = \frac{\pi^2}{100}-\pi
Now that we know T_1(0.01), and we know -1 \leq f(0.01) \leq 1, we can give the bound
\left|f(0.01)-T_1(0.01)\right|&\leq \left|f(0.01)\right|+\left|T_1(0.01)\right|
&\leq 1 +\left| \frac{\pi^2}{100}-\pi\right|
&=1+\pi\left|1-\frac{\pi}{100}\right|
& \lt 1+\pi
& \lt 1+4=5
A more reasonable bound on the error is that it is less than 5.
Still more reasonably, we would not use T_1(x) to evaluate \sin(100) approximately. We would write \sin(100) = \sin(100-32\pi) and approximate the right hand side, which is roughly \sin(-\pi/6).

statement.p: Let f(x)=\arcsin x, and let T_2(x) be the second order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x). Give a reasonable bound on the error \left|f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)-T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right| using Equation. What is the exact value of the error \left|f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)-T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right|?

hint.p: Using Equation, \left|f\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)-T_2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\right| = \left|\dfrac{f^{(3)}(c)}{3!}\left(\dfrac{1}{2}-0\right)^{3}\right| for some c in \left(0,\dfrac{1}{2}\right).

answer.p:
Using Equation,
\left|f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)-T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right|& \lt \frac{1}{10}.
The actual error is \left|f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)-T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right|&= \frac{\pi}{6}-\frac{1}{2}
which is about 0.02.

solution.p:
for some c in \left(0,\frac{1}{2}\right). We also found that
\frac{1+2c^2}{48\left(\sqrt{1-c^2}\right)^5} \lt \frac{1}{10}

when c is in \left(0,\frac{1}{2}\right). We conclude
\left|f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)-T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right| \lt \frac{1}{10}.

For the second part of the question, we need to find f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) and T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right). Finding f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) is not difficult.
f(x)&=\arcsin x
f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)&=\arcsin\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{\pi}{6}
In order to find T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right), we need to find T_2(x).
T_2(x)&=f(0)+f'(0)x+\frac{1}{2}f''(0)x^2
Conveniently, we've already found the first few derivatives of f(x). T_2(x)&=\arcsin(0)+\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-0^2}}\right)x+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{0}{\left(\sqrt{1-0^2}\right)^3}\right)x^2
&=0+x+0
&=x
T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)&=\frac{1}{2}
So, the actual error is \left|f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)-T_2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right|&=\left| \frac{\pi}{6}-\frac{1}{2}\right|= \frac{\pi}{6}-\frac{1}{2}
A calculator tells us that this is about 0.02.

statement.p: Let f(x)=\log(x), and let T_n(x) be the nth order Taylor polynomial for f(x) about x=1. You use T_n(1.1) to estimate \log (1.1). If your estimation needs to have an error of no more than 10^{-4}, what is an acceptable value of n to use?

hint.p: It helps to have a formula for f^{(n)}(x). You can figure it out by taking several derivatives and noticing the pattern, but also this has been given previously in the text.

answer.p: Any n greater than or equal to 3.

solution.p: So, our goal for the problem is to find a value of n that makes \dfrac{1}{(n+1)10^{n+1}}\le10^{-4}. Certainly, n=3 is such a number. Therefore, any n greater than or equal to 3 is an acceptable value.

statement.p: Give an estimation of \sqrt[7]{2200} using a Taylor polynomial. Your estimation should have an error of less than 0.001.

hint.p: You can approximate the function f(x)=x^{\tfrac{1}{7}}.
It's a good bit of trivia to know 3^7=2187.

A low order Taylor approximation will give you a good enough estimation. If you guess an order, and take that Taylor polynomial, the error will probably be less than 0.001 (but you still need to check).

solution.p: We will approximate f(x)=x^{\tfrac{1}{7}} using a Taylor polynomial. Since 3^7=2187, we will use x=2187 as our centre.

p.textred: We need to figure out which order Taylor polynomial will result in a small-enough error.

solution.p: So, actually, the linear Taylor polynomial (or any higher order Taylor polynomial) will result in an approximation that is much more accurate than required. (We don't know, however, that the constant approximation will be accurate enough--so we'd better stick with n \geq 1.)

hint.p: Use the 6th order Maclaurin approximation for f(x)=\sin x.

statement.p:
In this question, we use the remainder of a Maclaurin polynomial to approximate e.
Write out the 4th order Maclaurin polynomial T_4(x) of the function e^x.
Compute T_4(1).
Use your answer from to conclude \dfrac{326}{120} \lt e \lt \dfrac{325}{119}.

hint.p: For part , after you plug in the appropriate values to Equation, simplify the upper and lower bounds for e separately. In particular, for the upper bound, you'll have to solve for e.

solution.p:
For every whole number n, the nth derivative of e^x is e^x. So:
T_4(x)=\sum_{n=0}^4\frac{e^0}{n!}x^n =\sum_{n=0}^4\frac{x^n}{n!}
Remark: \dfrac{326}{120}\approx 2.717, and \dfrac{325}{119}\approx 2.731.
